Nayu |nativename= ภาษามลายูบางกอก
بڠكوق ملايو
'نايو |states=[[Thailand]] |ethnicity=[[Thai Malays]] |region=[[Bangkok]] |speakers=c. 5,000. |date= 2007 |familycolor=Austronesian |fam2=[[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] (MP) |fam3=[[Nuclear Malayo-Polynesian languages|Nuclear MP]] |fam4=[[Malayo-Sumbawan languages|Malayo-Sumbawan]] |fam5=[[Malayic languages|Malayic]] |fam6=[[Malayan languages|Malayan]] |fam7=[[Malay language|Malay]] |fam8=[[Kelantan-Pattani Malay]]/[[Kedah Malay]] |script=[[Jawi script]], [[Thai script]] |iso3= |isoexception= dialect |glotto= |glottorefname= |notice= }} '''Bangkok Malay''' also referred as '''Bangkok Melayu''' or '''Nayu''' is the local variant of [[Malay language|Malay]] spoken by ethnic [[Malay people|Malays]] living in [[Bangkok]] and its surrounding areas. It arose after the intermingling of Malay community from [[Southern Thailand]] and slowly diverge as a distinct variety of Malay. Despite historical Malay presence in what is now Bangkok dated as early as [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]] era, the dialect nonetheless only began to develop after the settlement of deportees from [[Kedah]], [[Kelantan]], [[Pattani]], [[Satun]] and [[Yaring District|Yaring]] dating from 1786. The speakers of Bangkok Malay can be found throughout the city, with higher concentration in Malay enclaves in [[Thon Buri District|Thon Buri]], [[Thung Khru District|Thung Khru]], [[Phra Pradaeng District|Phra Pradaeng]], [[Bang Kho Laem District|Bang Kho Laem]], [[Phra Khanong District|Phra Khanong]], [[Khlong Saen Saep]], [[Min Buri District|Min Buri]], [[Nong Chok District|Nong Chok]], [[Bang Nam Priao District|Bang Nam Priao]], [[Chachoengsao Province|Chachoengsao]], [[Thon Buri District|Thon Buri]] and [[Pom Prap Sattru Phai District|Pom Prap Sattru Phai]].{{cite web |url=http://www.aksorn.com/lib/detail_print.php?topicid=411 |title=เรื่องความเป็นมาของศาสนาอิสลามในประเทศไทย |publisher=Aksorn |location=Thailand |language=Thai|date=28 September 2016}} There are several variations of the dialect, owing to various waves and origin of Malay settlement in the city. The dialect was largely based on Pattani Malay with visible divergent from the original spoken in the south, this allowed Bangkok Malay to constitute as a separate dialect from Pattani Malay. Another notable sub-dialect of Bangkok Malay spoken in [[Bang Bua Thong District|Bang Bua Thong]] and [[Pak Kret District|Tha It]] districts demonstrating a strong [[Kedah Malay language|Kedahan]] influence, this correlates to the fact that most Malay people from these areas are the descendant of deportees that were bought from a village in western [[Yala province|Yala]] in the 18th century, who spoke with a Kedahan dialect.{{cite web |url=http://www.tci-thaijo.org/index.php/JLC/article/view/23596/20081 |title=Bang Bua Thong Dialect - a lexicon study|publisher= |location=Thailand |language=Thai|date=13 October 2016}} Following the rise of urbanism and the assimilation with the larger [[Thaification|Thai majority]], the language is now highly confined with adult over the age of 40 with varied fluency among younger generations. ==See also== *[[Thai Malays]] *[[Kelantan-Pattani Malay]] *[[Kedah Malay]] *[[Malayan languages]] === Notes === === Bibliography === * Umaiyah Haji Umar (2003), ''The assimilation of Bangkok-Melayu communities in the Bangkok metropolis and surrounding areas'', [[Ann Arbor]]: [[the University of Michigan]], [https://books.google.com.my/books/about/The_assimilation_of_Bangkok_Melayu_commu.html?id=Yu1uAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y online edition] * Umaiyah Haji Umar (2007), ''Language and Writing System of Bangkok Melayu", International Conference on Minority Languages and Writing Systems, [http://www.sabrizain.org/malaya/library/bkmlang.pdf online edition] * Umaiyah Haji Umar (2005), ''Bang Bua Thong Melayu Dialect - a Lexicon Study'', Journal Language and Culture, [[Bangkok]]:The Research Institute for Languages and Cultures of Asia (RILCA), [[Mahidol University]], [http://www.tci-thaijo.org/index.php/JLC/article/view/23596/20081 online edition] * Siti Munirah binti Kassim (2014), ''Sosio Budaya dan Identiti Etnik Melayu di Thailand'', [[Kuala Lumpur]]:Jabatan Pengajian Asia Tenggara, [[Universiti Malaya]], [https://www.academia.edu/6899862/SOSIO_BUDAYA_DAN_IDENTITI_ETNIK_MELAYU_DI_THAILAND_KAJIAN_PERBANDINGAN_ANTARA_MELAYU_BANGKOK_DENGAN_MELAYU_PATANI online edition] {{ms icon}} [[Category:Agglutinative languages]] [[Category:Languages of Thailand]] [[Category:Malayic languages]] [[Category:Malay dialects]] {{Languages of Thailand}} {{austronesian-lang-stub}}

{{Other uses}} [[File:Cabin boy ou mousse 1799.jpg|thumb|Cabin boy, 1799]] A '''cabin boy''' or '''ship's boy''' is a [[boy]] (in the sense of low-ranking young male employee, not always a minor in the juridical sense) who waits on the officers and passengers of a [[ship]],<ref>''Concise Oxford Dictionary'', Oxford University Press 1999, entry "Cabin boy"</ref> especially running errands for the captain. ==Duties== Cabin boys were usually 13–16 years old, but sometimes as young as 8,<ref>https://books.google.es/books?id=cVcAAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&lpg=PA174&dq=%22cabin+boys%22+%22as+young+as%22&source=bl&ots=MC1-9kyYDS&sig=iTwIO4e4lfK8JqdQSpY3FdPes_g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwixmbGyxfDcAhUpLsAKHZ2uDFMQ6AEwDXoECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22cabin%20boys%22%20%22as%20young%20as%22&f=false</ref> and also helped the cook in the [[galley (kitchen)|ship's kitchen]] and carried buckets of food from the ship's kitchen to the [[forecastle]] where the ordinary seamen ate. They would have to run from one end of the ship to the other carrying messages and become familiar with the sails, lines and ropes and the use of each in all sorts of weather. They would have to scramble up the rigging into the yards whenever the sails had to be trimmed. They would occasionally stand watch like other crewmen or act as helmsman in good weather, holding the wheel to keep the ship steady on her course.
==Royal Navy officers== Several prominent British Royal Navy officers began their career as cabin boys. The list includes officers that achieved an admiralty rank before 1801. * Admiral of the Fleet [[Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet of Shenstone]] * Admiral of the Fleet Sir [[Cloudsley Shovell]] * Admiral Sir [[Francis Drake]] * Admiral Sir [[John Hawkins (naval commander)|John Hawkins]] * Admiral (General) [[Richard Deane (regicide)|Richard Deane]] * Admiral (Colonel) [[William Rainsborough]] * Admiral Sir [[William Penn (Royal Navy officer)|William Penn]] * Vice Admiral Lord [[Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson|Nelson]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[William Batten]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[John Lawson (naval officer)|John Lawson]] * Vice Admiral (Captain) Badilow * Vice Admiral Sir [[Thomas Tiddeman]] * Vice Admiral (Captain) James Peacock * Vice Admiral (Captain) William Goodson * Vice Admiral Sir [[Christopher Myngs]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[John Harman (Royal Navy officer)|John Harman]] * Rear Admiral Sir [[John Berry (Royal Navy officer)|John Berry]] * Rear Admiral Sir [[Richard Stainer]] * Rear Admiral (Captain) Anthony Houlding * Rear Admiral (Captain) Deacons * Rear Admiral (Captain) Robert Sansum
==Notable cabin boys== *[[John Anglin (Medal of Honor)|John Anglin]], cabin boy who received the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[American Civil War]]. *[[Hobart Bosworth]], cabin boy on the ''[[Sovereign of the Seas (clipper)|Sovereign of the Seas]]'' who became a famous actor. *[[Christian Franzen]], cabin boy who served in the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]].<ref>'Wisconsin Blue Book 1915,' Biographical Sketch of Chris Franzen, pg. 519</ref> *[[Michael A. Healy|Michael Healy]], cabin boy in 1854, who became the first African-American to command a ship of the United States Government. *[[James Machon]], cabin boy who received the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[American Civil War]]. *[[Thomas Nickerson]], cabin boy on the ''[[Essex (1799 whaleship)|Essex]]'' who later wrote about the shipwreck and subsequent three months of survival at sea. *[[John H. Paynter]], cabin boy who enlisted in 1884, later became a real estate developer and writer of poetry and nonfiction, including the acclaimed ''Fugitive of the Pearl'' (1930). *[[John Ward Westcott]], cabin boy at the age of 13 and a [[Great Lakes]] captain at 20. He developed a special vessel mail system.
==Popular culture== {{Portal|Nautical}} *''[[Cori, de Scheepsjongen]]'' ("Cori the Cabin Boy"), a comics series by Belgian artist [[Bob de Moor]] about a cabin boy working for the [[Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie]] in the 16th century. *''[[Cabin Boy]]'', a 1994 film. *"Cabin Boy" a song by ''[[Tom Robinson]]'' from the 1984/1997 Castaway Northwest CNWVP006 album ''War Baby''. *''[[Captain Pugwash]]'', a British television children's animated series about a hapless captain and his crew; Tom, the cabin boy, is depicted as the most intelligent member of the crew. It is an [[urban myth]] that he was called 'Roger the cabin boy' (a slang sexual meaning of the name [[Roger]]). *''[[Treasure Island]]'', where the main character Jim serves as a cabin boy on the board the ship the ''Hispaniola''. *"Cabin Boy", a short story by [[Damon Knight]]. *''[[Renaissance Festival]]'', The Cabin Boys, Pirate Fire Comedy act from Minnesota.
==References== <references />

{{Multiple issues| {{Disputed|date=June 2018}} {{Notability|date=June 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=June 2018}} }}
The '''caste system among Indian Christians''' often reflects stratification by sect, location, and the [[Indian caste system|castes]] of their predecessors.<ref name="britannica">[http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9360711/Christian-caste Christian Castes] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129202451/http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9360711/Christian-caste# |date=2006-11-29 }} Encyclopædia Britannica</ref> The caste system today is beyond Hinduism (Hindu society) and it exists in most religions in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scroll.in/article/802759/beyond-hinduism-is-caste-a-religious-or-a-regional-problem|title=Beyond Hinduism: Is caste a religious or a regional problem?}}</ref>
Caste distinctions among Indian Christians are breaking down at about the same rate as those among Indians belonging to other religions. There exists evidence to show that Christian individuals have mobility within their respective castes.<ref name="fuller">{{cite journal |title=Kerala Christians and the Caste System |first=C. J. |last=Fuller |journal=Man |series=New series |volume=11 |issue=1 |date=March 1976 |pages=53–70 |jstor=2800388 |subscription=yes}}</ref> But, in some cases, social inertia causes old traditions and biases against other castes to remain, causing caste segregation to persist among Indian Christians.<ref name="britannica2">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9082413/Christian-caste|title=Christian caste|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=kBTkAAAAMAAJ Struggle for justice to Untouchable Christians] Brojendra Nath Banerjee, Uiliyāma Kerī Sṭāḍi eyāṇḍ Risārca Seṇṭāra. Page 42: "At stake is the fate of 16 million Christians of SC origin, who form 70–80 percent of the Christians in the country"</ref><ref>Carol Henderson Garcia, Carol E. Henderson 2002:40 "Today about 70 percent of Christians are Dalits"</ref><ref>Radhakrishnan 2005:23</ref><ref>Azariah 1985:5</ref>
Christian priests, nuns, Dalits and similar groups are also found in [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]], and [[Nepal]].<ref>{{cite book|title = Ethnographic discourse of the other: conceptual and methodological issues|pages = 39–116|author1=Panchanan Mohanty |author2=Ramesh C. Malik |author3=Eswarappa Kasi |publisher = Cambridge Scholars|year = 2009}}</ref>
There are sections of Christians in India like in Odisha, West Bengal, etc. who do not belong to any caste having lost caste at conversion. Sometimes, this practise from generations has contributed to an integrated society.
==Kerala== [[Roman Catholics]] in Kerala consist of [[Latin Catholics]], [[Syro-Malabar Catholic Church]] & [[Syro-Malankara Catholic Church]].<ref>http://www.kcbcsite.com/kerala1.php</ref> Syrian Christians in Kerala consist of the members of the [[Syro-Malabar Catholic Church]] and [[Syro-Malankara Catholic Church]], both ''[[sui iuris]]'' [[Eastern Catholic Churches]] under Roman Catholic church, as well as the [[Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church]], [[Malankara Jacobite Syrian Orthodox Church]], [[Malankara Mar Thoma Syrian Church]], [[Chaldean Syrian Church]], and Syrian Christians of the [[Madhya Kerala Diocese]] of the [[Church of South India]], which is a united autonomous Indian church within the [[Anglican Communion]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.csimkd.net/History.aspx# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128075052/http://www.csimkd.net/History.aspx# |archive-date=2016-01-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Goa== In the Indian state of [[Goa]], mass conversions were carried out by Portuguese Latin Catholic missionaries from the 16th century onwards. The Hindu converts retained their caste practices due to the involuntary nature of the mass conversions. This led to a lack of conscientious belief in Christian practices which perpetuated the existence of the social stratification. The Portuguese colonists, even during the [[Goan Inquisition]], did not do anything to change the caste system. Thus, the original Hindu [[Brahmins]] in Goa, the only caste that could be ordained, now became Christian ''[[Roman Catholic Brahmin|Bamonns]]'' and the [[Kshatriya]] and [[Vaishya Vani]]s became Christian noblemen called ''[[Roman Catholic Kshatriya|Chardos]]'' . Those Vaishya Vanis who could not get admitted into the ''Chardo'' caste became ''Gauddos'', and [[Shudra]]s became ''Sudirs''. Finally, the [[Dalit]]s or "Untouchables" who converted to Christianity became ''Maharas'' and ''Chamars'' (an appellation of the anti-Dalit ethnic slur ''Chamaar'').
==Tamil Nadu== Christians in the state belong to the [[Vellalar]], [[Udayar (caste)|Udaiyar]], [[Paravar]], [[Nadar (caste)|Nadar]], [[Adi Dravida]]r, and other Castes. Mass conversion of [[Paravar]]s date back to the Portuguese era and the conflict over the [[Pearl Fishery Coast]] between the Paravars and Arabs in the 15th century A.D.The Paravars converted 'en masse' to Christianity and became the subjects of the Portuguese King. The [[Nadar (caste)|Nadar]] conversion to Christianity dates back to the British Colonial era in the 18th-century. The first to initiate the conversion was [[Mylaudy]] Village by Sir Ringle Taube. Later in the 19th century, the [[Vellalar]]s, the [[Udayar (caste)|Udaiyars]] and [[Schedule castes]] embraced Christianity. The cohesion of ''[[Jāti|jati]]s'' among caste [[Christian]]s (e.g. [[Paravas]]) and the strength of caste leadership are noted by scholars to be much stronger than comparable predominantly [[Hindu]] castes in [[Tamil Nadu]].<ref name="kau">Kauffman, S. B. "A Christian Caste in Hindu Society: Religious Leadership and Social Conflict among the Paravas of Southern Tamilnadu." ''Modern Asian Studies''. 15, No. 2, (1981)</ref>
==Under the law== Indian law does not provide benefits for "Untouchable Christians", however Christians have been agitating for the same rights given to [[Hindu]], [[Buddhist]], and [[Sikh]] [[Scheduled castes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/04/21/by-2050-india-to-have-worlds-largest-populations-of-hindus-and-muslims/|title=By 2050, India to have world’s largest populations of Hindus and Muslims}}</ref> Despite the activists point of discrimination due to social tag or status, which doesn't go away, [[K. G. Balakrishnan]] asked: "Could the Christians admit that they practise caste system and that Dalits (among them) face social discrimination requiring reservation to uplift their cause? This is not all that easy."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/India/Do_Christians_also_practise_caste_system_asks_SC/articleshow/2218560.cms |title=Do Christians also practise caste system, asks SC |newspaper=Times of India |date=July 20, 2007}}</ref>
Some Christians also oppose the proposed labeling of "[[Christian]] [[Scheduled caste]]s" because they feel their identity may be assimilated. Pastor Salim Sharif of the [[Church of North India]] notes "We are becoming another class and caste."<ref>Sharif interview 17 November 1996</ref>
==Caste discrimination among Christians== ===Incidence===
Presently in India, more than [[Socio Economic and Caste Census_2011#Distribution | 42 per cent]] of Indian Christians are [[Dalits]], but the higher caste [[Catholic]]s control 90 per cent of the Catholic churches administrative jobs. According to Dalit Christians website, out of the 156 [[catholic]] bishops, only six are from lower castes. <ref>[http://www.dalitchristians.com/Html/arulappa.htm Problems and Struggles] Dalitchristians.com</ref>
===Criticism=== Untouchable Catholics have spoken out against discrimination against them by members of the Catholic Church. A Dalit activist with a ''nom-de-plume'' of Bama Faustina has written books that are critical of the discrimination by the nuns and priests in Churches in South India (CSI).<ref>[http://www.hinduonnet.com/2001/09/16/stories/1316017m.htm A palmyra leaf that sears us] [[The Hindu]] – September 16, 2001</ref> During 2003 [[ad limina]] visits of the bishops of India, [[Pope John Paul II]] criticized the caste discrimination in the [[Catholic Church in India]] when addressing bishops of the ecclesiastical provinces of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Madras and Mylapore|Madras-Mylapore]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Madurai|Madurai]] and [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Pondicherry and Cuddalore|Pondicherry-Cuddalore]], the three archbishops of Tamil Nadu. He went on to say: "It is the Church's obligation to work unceasingly to change hearts, helping all people to see every human being as a child of God, a brother or sister of Christ, and therefore a member of our own family".<ref>{{cite web|title=Address to the Bishops of India on their ad Limina visit|url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/speeches/2003/november/documents/hf_jp-ii_spe_20031117_ad-limina-india_en.html|accessdate=17 November 2003}}</ref><ref>[http://www.zenit.org/article-8716?l=english Papal Address to Bishops of Madras-Mylapore, Madurai and Pondicherry-Cuddalore] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922115639/http://zenit.org/article-8716?l=english# |date=2008-09-22 }} ZENIT – November 17, 2003</ref>
===Dalit Christians=== Mass conversions of lower caste Hindus took place in order to escape the discrimination. The main Dalit groups that participated in these conversions were Chuhras of Punjab, Chamars of North India (Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh), Vankars of Gujarat and Pulayas of Kerala.<ref name="Dalit Christians In India">[http://www.dalitstudies.org.in/uploads/publication/1473146694.pdf Dalit Christians In India] Sobin George 2012</ref> They believed that “Christianity is a true religion; a desire for protection from oppressors and, if possible, material aid; the desire for education for their children; and the knowledge that those who have become Christians had improved”.<ref>South Indian Missionary Congress. 1908. ‘The Report of Conference Held at Madras’</ref> Christianity was thought to be egalitarian and could provide mobility away from the caste. Even after conversion, Dalits were discriminated against due to the “residual leftover” practice of caste discrimination.<ref>[‘Homo Hierarchicus: The Caste System and its Implications’, Complete Revised Edition, Chicago: Chicago University Press] Dumont, Louis. 1980.</ref> This is attributed to the predominant Hindu society they lived in.The environment and power structures of the society they engaged in was the same. Sometimes the only change seen was their personal religious identity. In many cases they were still referred to by their Hindu caste names. Example Pulayans in Kerala, Pariah in Tamil Nadu and Madigas in Andra Pradesh.<ref>[‘Caste-based Discrimination and Atrocities on Dalit Christians and the Need for Reservations’, Working Paper Series, II(04): New Delhi: Indian Institute of Dalit Studies.] Louis, Prakash. 2007.</ref>
The first people converted by Jesuits of the Madura Mission to Christianity were members of Nadars, Maravars and Pallars (untouchables).<ref>[The Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute Vol. 2, No. 3 (Sep., 1996)] David Mosse.</ref> Caste based occupations held by Dalits also show a clear segregation which perpetuated even after becoming Christian. Occupational patterns (including manual scavenging) are prevalent among Dalit Christians in north-west India are quite similar to that of Dalit Hindus.<ref>[ ‘Rural Christian Community in North West India’, New Delhi] Dogar, Vidya Sagar. 2000.</ref> Occupational discrimination for Dalit Christians goes so far as to restrict not only employment but also clean sanitation and water.<ref>Jose, Kananaikil. 1990. [‘Scheduled Castes Converts and Social Disabilities: A Survey of Tamil Nadu’]</ref> Inter caste marriage among Christians is also not commonly practiced. For example, Syrian Christians in Kerala do not marry Dalit Christians. Even intermarriage between Bamons and Sudras in Goa is quite uncommon. Sometimes marriage to a higher class Hindu is preferred to marriage to a Dalit Christian. Discrimination against Dalit Christians also remained in interactions and mannerisms between castes for example ‘lower caste christians’ had to close their mouth when talking to a Syrian Christian.<ref name="Dalit Christians In India"/> Even after conversion segregation, restriction, hierarchy and graded ritual purity remained. Data shows that there is more discrimination and less class mobility in rural areas.<ref name="Dalit Christians In India"/>
In many cases, the churches themselves perpetuated the caste system. Some churches referred to the Dalits as ‘New Christians'. It is a derogatory term that classifies the Dalit Christians in order to allow other Christians to look down upon them. In many churches in south India Dalits had either separate seating or had to attend the mass from outside.<ref>Louis, Prakash. 2007.[ ‘Caste-based Discrimination and Atrocities on Dalit Christians and the Need for Reservations’, Working Paper Series, II(04): New Delhi: Indian Institute of Dalit Studies.]</ref> Dalit Christians are also grossly underrepresented amongst the clergy.<ref>[Indian Dalits find no refuge from caste in Christianity] BBC, sept 14 2010</ref> There are a few churches that accept the reality of castes in Christianity and discrimination towards dalits. Catholic Bishops’ Conference of India and the National Council of Churches in India have backed changes in the church and law to benefit Dalit Christians.
==See also== *[[Christianity in India]] *[[Caste system among Muslims]] *[[Dalit theology]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Cat Aficionado Association |image = |image_border = |size = 200px |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = {{start date and age|2001}} |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = |region_served = China |membership = |language = Chinese |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = }}
The '''Cat Aficionado Association''' ('''CAA''')<ref>{{cite book | last = Chen | first = Hui-wen | title = The Mythology of Cats | publisher = Baihua Literature and publishing house | location = China | year = 2005 | url = https://translate.google.com/translate?prev=_t&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bhpubl.com.cn%2F1chanpin%2Fadmin%2Fshow2.asp%3Farticleid%3D685&sl=zh-CN&history_state0= | isbn = 7-5306-4362-2 }}</ref> is China's largest registry of pedigreed cats and is recognized internationally in conjunction with [[American Cat Fanciers Association]] (ACFA) as the premiere pedigreed cat registering association in Asia. Headquartered in Beijing, China, CAA was established officially March 3, 2001.
[[Image:CAA international logo for distribution.jpg|frame|right|CAA logo]]
To enter the international arena, CAA established a partnership with ACFA in 2002. CAA abides by ACFA standards, and invites ACFA judges to preside over its official competitive events.
==Purpose== CAA's official goal is to publicize and promote [[pedigreed]] breeds of cats and to propagate the well-being of all non-pedigree cats, domestic, stray, feral or wild. CAA<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Bense |first=Fabio |work=Cães & Cia |lang=pt-BR |publisher=Forix Editoria |location=Brazil |date=January 2009 |issue=356 |page=12 |issn=1413-3040}}</ref>{{complete citation needed|date=August 2018|reason=Missing article title.}} also promotes one of China's most popular native breeds, the [[Dragon Li]] ({{lang|zh-Latn|Li Hua Mau}}). The CAA logo design depicts a stylized Dragon Li.
==Activities== CAA is evolving as an organization, with various programs such as [[Animal rescue group|cat rescue]], and a [[trap–neuter–return]] (TNR) effort for thousands of documented feral and abandoned felines throughout Asia. CAA also trains and assists catteries, and purebred feline owners in [[Breed registry|registering]] pedigrees.
Like most such organizations, it also organizes competitive [[cat show]]s. CAA's third show (January 1–3, 2004, in Beijing) was briefly documented, in English, by a visiting Canadian ACFA member in 2004 on a website, including photographs of two CAA breeds, the Chinese White and the Dragon Li; ACFA's Dolores Kennedy and Barb Belanger were guest all-breed judges at the event.<ref name="Belanger">{{cite web |first=Barb J. |last=Belanger |title=Cat Aficionado Association: The Show – January 1, 2 and 3 |date=2005 |via=Members.Shaw.ca |publisher=self-published |url=http://members.shaw.ca:80/bjbelanger/China.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070430032756/http://members.shaw.ca/bjbelanger/China.htm# |archive-date=2007-04-30 |access-date=31 July 2018 |df= }} Zero of the numerous Internet Archive captures of this site saved all of the photos on it, but they can all be recovered by looking at different saves on different dates.</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
{{Infobox horseracing personality |name = Chic Anderson |image = |caption = |occupation = Thoroughbred horse race caller |birth_place = [[Evansville, Indiana]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1931|12|17}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|1979|03|24|1931|12|17}} |death_place = [[Commack, New York]] |career wins = |race = |awards = |horses = |updated = }}
'''Charles David (Chic) Anderson''' (December 17, 1931 – March 24, 1979) was an American [[sportscaster]] and [[public address]] [[announcer]] specializing in Thoroughbred [[horse racing]]. He was one of American sports' most famous PA voices, and remains among its most revered [[race caller]]s.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1979/03/25/archives/charles-chic-anderson-dies-well-known-race-caller-was-47.html ''New York Times'' archives, March 25, 1979 obituary Charles (Chic) Anderson]</ref>
==Racing background== A native of [[Evansville, Indiana]], Anderson got his start in horse racing in 1951, working part-time in the mutuel department at Dade Park (now [[Ellis Park Racecourse]]) in nearby [[Henderson, Kentucky]]. Eight years later, in 1959, Anderson became track announcer.
The following year, in 1960, Anderson also became the public-address voice of [[Churchill Downs]], home of the [[Kentucky Derby]]. He would call 16 Runs for the Roses between then and 1977. During that stretch, Anderson also worked as a Midwest sports anchor, gaining the TV experience that would serve him well nationally in the 1970s.
In addition to Ellis and Churchill, Anderson worked at [[Oaklawn Park]], [[Santa Anita Park]], [[Ak-Sar-Ben (arena)|Ak-Sar-Ben]] and [[Arlington Park]] racetracks in the 1960s and 1970s.
Starting in 1969, Anderson's Derby calls would not only be heard by Churchill patrons but also on the [[CBS]] Television Network, where he assumed [[Jack Drees]]' role on the network's coverage of all three [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]] races, as well as other thoroughbred events. Anderson would eventually gain a level of fame as a national race caller exceeded only by that of [[Clem McCarthy]] and [[Ted Husing]].
Because of his TV experience and knowledge of horses, CBS adopted him as a full-fledged member of their sportscasting team for big races, providing jockey interviews and insights as well as the race calls.
Anderson would remain at Churchill Downs until May 1977. After calling [[Seattle Slew]]'s victory in the Derby for both Churchill and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] Television, he moved his base of operations to the [[New York Racing Association]] tracks (including [[Belmont Park]]), succeeding NYRA race caller [[Dave Johnson (announcer)|Dave Johnson]]. That allowed him to call Slew's victory in the 1977 [[Belmont Stakes]] for the racetrack, which likely makes Anderson the only man to call two Triple Crown races on the tracks' public-address systems in one year.
During his NYRA tenure, Anderson's daily calls would not only be heard by fans at the track, but also on [[WCBS (AM)|WCBS Radio]].
In fall 1978, Anderson called Slew's last race, the [[Stuyvesant Handicap]] at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]], live for CBS Television, WCBS radio and, the Big A fans. As Slew, ridden by [[Angel Cordero, Jr.]], roared down the stretch far enough in front to ensure a win, Anderson emoted. "Ladies and gentlemen, here he is, the champion of the world, Seattle Slew!"
=="A tremendous machine!"== For CBS Television, Anderson authored the two most famous calls in horse-racing history—and two of the most famous sportscasts in TV history—the Triple Crown clinchings in the [[Belmont Stakes]] of 1973 and 1978.
He was behind the CBS mic on June 9, 1973, when Derby and [[Preakness Stakes]] winner [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]] tried to become the first horse in a quarter century to win the Crown. A stunned Anderson punctuated Big Red's powerful move on the final turn of the '73 Belmont this way, focusing on Secretariat while still keeping tabs on the other horses' positions:{{quote|They're on the turn, and Secretariat is blazing along! The first three-quarters of a mile in 1:09 and four fifths. Secretariat is widening now! He is moving like a tremendous machine! Secretariat by twelve, Secretariat by fourteen lengths on the turn! Sham is dropping back. It looks like they'll catch him today, as My Gallant and Twice a Prince are both coming up to him now. But Secretariat is all alone! He's out there almost a sixteenth of a mile away from the rest of the horses! Secretariat is in a position that seems impossible to catch. He's into the stretch. Secretariat leads this field by 18 lengths, and now Twice a Prince has taken second and My Gallant has moved back to third. They're in the stretch. Secretariat has opened a 22 length lead! He is going to be the Triple Crown winner! Here comes Secretariat to the wire. An unbelievable, an amazing performance! He hits the finish 25 lengths in front! It's going to be Twice a Prince second, My Gallant third, Private Smiles fourth, and [[Sham (horse)|Sham]], who had it today, dropped back to fifth.}}
A few minutes later, reviewing the videotape of Secretariat's stretch romp, Anderson humbly admitted it was hard to count lengths as Secretariat raced toward home. "I said twenty-five," Anderson said. "It could conceivably have been more."
In fact, the champion's winning margin was fully 31 lengths—a distance it took careful examination of videotape and trackside photographs to measure. Secretariat was so far ahead when he crossed the finish line that the TV camera operator had to pan to the left to pick up the rest of the field, in lieu of leaving an "empty" track in the viewer's line of sight for a few seconds.
=="We'll test these two to the wire!"== Five years later, for both CBS Sports and the Belmont Park fans, Anderson called a Belmont Stakes race that was as close as the 1973 Belmont was a romp.
[[Affirmed]] and [[Alydar]]—who battled each other closely both as 2-year-old horses and in the 1978 Triple Crown races (with Affirmed prevailing barely in both the Derby and Preakness)—renewed their battle in that year's Belmont. They hooked up in earnest a half-mile into the race and held a virtual match race for the rest of the event.{{quote|It is still Affirmed as they come to the quarter pole. He's holding on to a head lead. Alydar is outside of him and challenging that lead. The two are heads apart and Alydar's got a lead! Alydar put a head in front right in the middle of the stretch! It's Alydar and Affirmed battling back along the inside! We'll test these two to the wire! Affirmed under a left-hand whip! Alydar on the outside driving! Affirmed and Alydar heads apart. Affirmed's got a nose in front as they come on the wire!}}
Then, shutting off the PA microphone (as track announcers did then) but keeping his CBS mic hot, he described the final moment of victory:{{quote|At the finish, it's going to be dead tight—Affirmed won it! He wins the Triple Crown. Alydar is second! Steve Cauthen salutes the crowd. Darby Creek Road in third, Judge Advocate fourth, and Noon Time Spender finished fifth—and what a stirring stretch battle! They both had their shot at this one during the stretch run!}}
==Voice of racing== Anderson's style as a public-address announcer—even when the PA call was also carried on TV—was low-key, almost robotic, at the start of a race. (On arena PA systems, rapid-fire calls often end up a blur to the ears of fans scattered throughout a track or stadium). Then Anderson would pick up a vibrant pace halfway through the race.
Anderson used a more animated style at the start when his call aired only on TV, maintaining a brisk pace while remaining measured, avoiding the cliches and the screaming style other track announcers adopted in the 1980s and beyond.
==Prince Thou Ain't== Anderson's only prominent mistake came in the 1975 Derby, which he called for both the Churchill fans and ABC Television.
Confused by the similar silks of Foolish Pleasure and Prince Thou Art, he described Prince Thou Art as the leader during the late stages of the race, before correcting himself near the end. A newspaper headline on Anderson's rare error read "Prince Thou Ain't".
History-minded observers compared it to a similar mistake that announcer Clem McCarthy had made during the running of the 1947 [[Preakness Stakes]].
==Death== Anderson died of a [[heart attack]] on March 24, 1979, at his home in [[Commack, New York]], on [[Long Island]]. He was succeeded at both NYRA and CBS by his backup, [[Marshall Cassidy]].

revision.text:
{{copy edit|date=October 2018}}
[[File:CriancaLixao20080220MarcelloCasalJrAgenciaBrasil.jpg|thumb]][[Child labor]] is one of [[Brazil]]'s biggest social issues. According to data from the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) in 2015, more than 2.7 million young people between 5 and 17 years of age work in the country, 79,000 of these children between 5 and 9 years of age.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.correiobraziliense.com.br/app/noticia/economia/2017/06/11/internas_economia,601710/trabalho-infantil-atinge-2-7-milhoes-no-brasil.shtml|title=Trabalho infantil atinge 2,7 milhões de crianças e adolescentes no Brasil|last=Braziliense|first=Correio|date=2017-06-11|work=Correio Braziliense|access-date=2018-10-08|language=pt-BR}}</ref> Brazilian law establishes 16 as the minimum age for entering the labor market and 14 to work as an apprentice.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/direitos-humanos/noticia/2017-06/brasil-registra-aumento-de-casos-de-trabalho-infantil-entre|title=Brasil registra aumento de trabalho infantil entre crianças de 5 a 9 anos|date=2017-06-12|work=Agência Brasil|access-date=2018-10-08|language=pt-br}}</ref>
About 30% of child labor is in the agricultural sector; in terms of regions, 60% are in the North and Northeast regions. In terms of ethnicity, 65% are black children. In terms of gender, 70% of child laborers are male.<ref name=":2" /> According to the International Labor Organization (ILO), poverty is one of the main causes of child labor in the world, as is the case in Brazil. Children are forced to work in order to increase family income, putting aside studies and social life.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/portuguese/noticias/2003/030424_tconvecao.shtml|title=Convenções da OIT intesificam combate ao trabalho infantil {{!}} BBC Brasil {{!}} BBC World Service|website=bbc.com|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/portuguese/noticias/2003/030428_tperguntas.shtml|title=Tire suas dúvidas sobre trabalho infantil no Brasil {{!}} BBC Brasil {{!}} BBC World Service|website=bbc.com|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
Since the enactment of the 1988 Constitution which prohibits child labor,<ref name=":3" /> the Brazilian government has taken steps to reduce the prevalence of child labor, using international conventions as guidelines. Social movements such as the hashtag ''#ChegaDeTrabalhoInfantil'' were created to raise awareness of child labor in Brazil. Other steps included changes to labor laws, and added funding to welfare programs for families such as ''[[Bolsa Família]]'', a program by the Brazilian government to support poorer families in Brazil.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> The number of young people working decreased from about 8 million in 1992 to 5 million in 2003.<ref name=":5" />
Despite recent improvements, Brazil still accounts for a quarter of children working in Latin America. Between 2014 and 2015, there was a 13% increase in the number of working children under 10.<ref name=":2" /> In 2016, 1,238 reports of cases of child exploitation were registered in the Public Prosecutor's Office.<ref name=":2" /> Many cases of child labor in the informal economies went unrecorded, such as child prostitution or drug trafficking.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/811259893|title=Child labour's global past, 1650-2000|date=2011|publisher=Peter Lang|others=Lieten, Kristoffel., Nederveen Meerkerk, Elise van.|isbn=9783035102185|location=Bern|oclc=811259893}}</ref>
== Definition == In [[Constitution of Brazil|Brazil's constitution]], child labor is addressed under article 7, item 33. The item prohibits night work, as well as any work deemed "dangerous or unhealthy" for teenagers under 18 years. Minors under 16 are not allowed under the constitution to work at all, except for apprenticeships for minors 14 and up.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.direitonet.com.br/artigos/exibir/1610/O-trabalho-infantil-no-Brasil|title=O trabalho infantil no Brasil|work=DireitoNet|access-date=2018-10-09|language=pt-br}}</ref><ref>{{cite constitution |article=7 |clause=33 |polity=Brazil |date=1988 }}</ref>
However, on the international stage, definitions of child labor vary between organizations.
The term 'child labour', according to [[International Labour Organization|ILO]],<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilo.org/ipec/facts/lang--en/index.htm|title=What is child labour (IPEC)|website=ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> is defined as "work that deprives children of their childhood, their potential and their dignity, and that is harmful to physical and mental development". It refers to work that can cause damage to children mentally, physically, socially or morally, work that deprives children's ability to attend school, work that place heavy burdens on them alongside schoolwork. There is no universal definition of child labor according to ILO since the definition largely depends on the context of the working environment, the legal working age and the type of work engaged. Among all the forms of child labor, ILO defines child slavery, child prostitution, child crime-work (drug trafficking) and any work that jeopardizes the safety of children as the worst forms of child labor.<ref name=":6" />
[[UNICEF]] has different criteria for child labor. For children between 5 to 11 years old, actions are categorized as child labor if at least one hour of economic activity or at least 28 hours of domestic work was performed by them weekly. For children between 12 and 14 years of age, at least 14 hours of economic activity or at least 42 hours of economic activity and domestic work per week make them victims of child labor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/stats_popup9.html|title=UNICEF - Definitions|website=unicef.org|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
== History == Child labor issue has been a part of Brazilian history since 1500. However, because the notion of youth or child was not well defined until the middle of the nineteenth century in Brazil,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gutiérrez|first=Horácio|last2=Lewkowicz|first2=Ida|date=1999|title=Trabalho infantil em Minas Gerais na primeira metade do século XIX|url=https://locus.ufjf.emnuvens.com.br/locus/article/view/2342|journal=Locus - Revista de História|language=pt|volume=5|issue=2|issn=1413-3024}}</ref> there was limited information on child labor before the 20th century.<ref name=":0" /> Early documentations of Portuguese vessels indicated evidence of minors working in the 16th century for sea voyages as labor for immigrants from Portugal and other parts of Europe.<ref>{{Citation|last=Pestana Ramos|first=Fábio|title=A História Trágico-Marítima das crianças nas embarcações portuguesas do século XVI.|date=1999-01-01|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/275601988_A_Historia_Tragico-Maritima_das_criancas_nas_embarcacoes_portuguesas_do_seculo_XVI|pages=19–54|isbn=8572441123|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> Though children engaged in domestic work prior to the arrival of European settlers, the degree of child labor in Brazil worsened drastically after.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/930464628|title=Boas práticas : combate ao trabalho infantil no mundo|date=2015|publisher=DF|others=International Labour Office., Brazil. Ministério do Desenvolvimento Social e Combate à Fome., Brazil. Ministério do Trabalho e Emprego., Brazil. Ministério das Relações Exteriores.|isbn=9788560700868|location=Brasília|oclc=930464628}}</ref> The first organization to use minors as labor force was the [[Brazilian Navy]] during the [[Paraguayan War|Paraguay War]].<ref name=":0" /> Data suggests over 600 children between age 9 to age 12 were on the battlefield.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43628836|title=História das crianças no Brasil|date=1999|publisher=Editora Contexto|others=Del Priore, Mary.|isbn=8572441123|location=São Paulo, SP|oclc=43628836}}</ref> This involvement with military or contact with weapons characterizes some of the worst forms of child labor in Brazil, even in the present. Children in [[favela]]s are seen as valuable and desirable middlemen in drug trafficking since their minor status make them immune to legal prosecution according to the law.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Veloso|first=Leticia|date=2012-10-01|title=Child Street Labor in Brazil: Licit and Illicit Economies in the Eyes of Marginalized Youth|url=https://read.dukeupress.edu/south-atlantic-quarterly/article-abstract/111/4/663/3597/Child-Street-Labor-in-Brazil-Licit-and-Illicit|journal=South Atlantic Quarterly|language=en|volume=111|issue=4|pages=663–679|doi=10.1215/00382876-1724129|issn=0038-2876}}</ref> Not surprisingly, children were used widely as labor force during the [[Slavery in Brazil|slavery period]], working on plantations for sugar productions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48214253|title=Combatendo o trabalho infantil : guia para educadores.|date=2001|publisher=CENPEC-Centro de Estudos e Pesquisas em Educação, Cultura e Ação Comunitária, Programa Internacional para a Eliminação do Trabalho Infantil, IPEC, Organização Internacional do Trabalho, Escritório no Brasil|others=International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour., Centro de Estudos e Pesquisas em Educação, Cultura e Ação Comunitária.|isbn=9228110406|edition=1st|location=São Paulo, SP, Brasil|oclc=48214253}}</ref> Slaveholders embraced the idea of making children of slaves work since the overall productivity increases without purchasing more slaves.<ref name=":1">Child Labour's Global Past, 1650-2000". eds.b.ebscohost.com.</ref>
Industrialization in Brazil, starting from the late 19th century, carried on the exploitation of children post-slavery. Capitalists were willing to take in minors since there was no regulation against child labor and children are of low cost. In São Paulo, the center of industrialization where large workforces were demanded, there were advertisements published by textile sectors to recruit children in the mid-1870s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mulheres e menores no trabalho industrial: os fatores sexo e idade na dinâmica do capita|last=Moura|first=Esmeralda|publisher=|year=1982|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> The majority of the working class of São Paulo was composed of poor immigrants, and the work of immigrant children was a valuable source of income that some families depended on.<ref name=":7" /> In 1890, 25 percent of São Paulo's textile industry labor force was made up of children.<ref name=":0" /> In Rio de Janeiro, 64 percent of workers in a textile factory were children in 1865.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/27266945|title=História da indústria e do trabalho no Brasil : das origens aos anos 20|last=1952-|first=Foot, Francisco,|date=1991|publisher=Editora Atica|others=Leonardi, Victor, 1942-|isbn=8508037562|edition= 2nd|location=São Paulo|oclc=27266945}}</ref> Children suffered physical injuries or death due to the harsh work engaged in, the poor working conditions, and the violent treatment from their business owners. Armando Dias, a minor worker in the textile industry, was killed by an electric shock during work in November 1913.<ref name=":7" /> When teenager Francisco Augusto de Fonseca didn't perform his job up to the owner's expectation, his face was brutally hit by the owner.<ref name=":7" /> Child labor during this period was seen as a necessity: capitalists exploited the low cost of minor workers and used them to suppress the wages for adult workers; poor families also needed children to work to support their life.<ref name=":0" />
Attempts to protect the rights of children and regulate child labor emerged during the late 19th century.<ref name=":0" /> There was a decree in 1891 that concerned minor employees in the factories of the Federal Capital.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Campos|first=Herculano Ricardo|date=2001|title=TRABALHO INFANTIL PRODUTIVO E DESENVOLVIMENTO HUMANO|url=http://www.scielo.br/pdf/pe/v8n1/v8n1a15|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> In 1912, the Brazilian Labour Confederation was established, pushing for restrictions on child labor.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Anarquistas_e_comunistas_no_Brasil.html?id=bKNAAAAAYAAJ|title=Anarquistas e comunistas no Brasil: 1900-1935|last=Dulles|first=John W. F.|date=1977|publisher=Nova Frontera|language=pt}}</ref> In 1917, workers in São Paulo went on strike, their demands including eradication of night work for workers under the age of 18 and total eradication of work for those under 14. In 1919, a law passed in São Paulo restricted legal working age to 14 years old. The constitutional amendments (1934,1937,1946) rendered any work performed by minors under 14 illegal. But during the military government ruling period, minimum working age was lowered to 12. The 1988 amendment, the 1998 amendment and a law in 2000 together made up of the current legal definition of child labor: prohibiting any form of hazardous work for minors under 18 and prohibiting any form of labor for minors under 16. The exception to this law is apprenticeships, which are allowed at 14.<ref name=":0" />
On February 2, 2000, the government ratified [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention|ILO convention 182]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312327|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications by Convention|website=ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> On June 28 of the same year, the Brazilian government ratified [[Minimum Age Convention, 1973|ILO convention 138]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312283|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications by Convention|website=ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref>
== Current situation == [[File:Child_Employment_Rate_Below_13.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Child_Employment_Rate_Below_13.jpg|thumb|222x222px]] [[File:Child_Employment_Rate.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Child_Employment_Rate.jpg|thumb]] Nowadays, through achievements made by the country it is clear that the Brazilian governments demonstrate considerable commitment and dedication to eradicate child labor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.todamateria.com.br/trabalho-infantil-no-brasil/|title=Trabalho Infantil no Brasil|work=Toda Matéria|access-date=2018-10-10|language=pt-br}}</ref> The [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics]] conducts the Brazilian National Household Sample Survey (PNAD) annually, first administered in 1981. This survey boosts the availability of data on child labor reports in the region. In 2005, more than 2.9 million children under the age of 17 engaged in some form of labor. This figure represents 7.8% of the age group back in 2005.<ref name=":0" />
The survey in 2016 indicates that 4.6% of the 5-17 age group (1.8 million out of 30 million) are working, which is a large improvement from 2005. In 2016, most of the minor employments are found in the age group 14-17. 0.2% of the 5-9 age group is working, 1.3% for the 10-13 age group, 6.4% for the 14-16 age group and 17% for the 16-17 age group. The extent to which child labor persists varies between regions. The North and the South have the highest child working rate at 5.7% and 6.3% respectively. For the age group under 14, the North and the Northeast have the highest rate at 1.5% and 1%. In terms of race, the black and brown (Preta e parda) population covers 64.1% of child labor as compared to the 35.9% of the white (Branca). In terms of gender, 65.3% are male children. 47.6% of children of 5–13 years are engaged in agricultural activities, while 21.4% of 14–17 years do so. In some cases agricultural duties are performed because they are seen as a part of the socialization process, but this does not negate the fact some children are forced to work in agriculture to compensate family incomes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://loja.ibge.gov.br/pnad-continua-trabalho-infantil-2016.html|title=PNAD Contínua - Trabalho Infantil|website=loja.ibge.gov.br|language=pt|access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref>
Despite the fact that the percentage of child labor is gradually decreasing, many children in Brazil are still engaged in child labor, including in hazardous fields. Within the agricultural sector, children fish and harvest mollusks, produce rice, soy, tobacco, and are involved in charcoal production.<ref>{{Cite book|title=O Trabalho Infantil no Brasil|last=|first=|publisher=ABRINQ Foundation|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Within the industrial sector, children work in quarries,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://redeglobo.globo.com/pi/redeclube/noticia/2013/08/globo-reporter-mostra-imagens-de-trabalho-infantil-no-estado-do-piaui.html|title=Globo Repórter mostra imagens de trabalho infantil no estado do Piauí|work=redeglobo.globo.com|access-date=2018-10-10|language=pt-br}}</ref> produce bricks,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://agenciaal.alesc.sc.gov.br/index.php/radioal/noticia_single_radioal/naeo-e-brincadeira-o-trabalho-infantil-que-santa-catarina-naeo-ve|title=Não é brincadeira: O trabalho infantil que Santa Catarina não vê|website=agenciaal.alesc.sc.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> and slaughter animals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.brazzil.com/23990-despite-strict-laws-child-labor-in-brazil-is-not-going-away|title=Despite Strict Laws, Child Labor in Brazil Is Not Going Away|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref> In the service sector, children are found doing street work such as garbage scavenging.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRC/C/BRA/CO/2-4&Lang=en|title=Treaty bodies Download|website=tbinternet.ohchr.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Child laborers doing street work also sometimes sell alcohol.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.opovo.com.br/app/maisnoticias/brasil/2016/06/12/noticiasbrasil,3623300/trabalho-infantil-no-nordeste-perpetua-o-ciclo-da-pobreza-e-miseria.shtml|title=Trabalho infantil no Nordeste perpetua o ciclo da pobreza e miséria|website=opovo.com.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Children are also made to work for criminal groups<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://epoca.globo.com/brasil/noticia/2017/01/traficantes-cariocas-recrutam-e-armam-criancas-cada-vez-mais-novas-para-o-crime.html|title=Traficantes cariocas recrutam e armam crianças cada vez mais novas para o crime|work=epoca.globo.com|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> or engage in prostitution.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://www.childrenwin.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/140509_Sexual-exploitation-of-children-in-Brazil_putting-a-spot-on-the-p....pdf|title=Sexual Exploitation of Children in Brazil: Putting a Spot on the Problem|last=des Hommes|first=Terre|date=May 9, 2014|work=|access-date=Oct 10, 2018}}</ref> Child sex tourism is common in coastal areas that usually attract tourists and girls from other South American countries are involved in commercial sex in Brazil.<ref name=":8" />
Currently, the efforts put in to further reduce child labor are working towards Goal 8 of the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] which "promotes sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/sustainable-development-goals/goal-8-decent-work-and-economic-growth.html|title=Goal 8: Decent work and economic growth {{!}} UNDP|website=UNDP|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref>
== Legal framework == {| class="wikitable" |+Laws on child labor !Standard !International Standard Compliance<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dol.gov/agencies/ilab/resources/reports/child-labor/brazil|title=Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor - Brazil|date=2016-09-30|work=United States Department of Labor|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> !Age !Legislation !Date of Enactment |- |Minimum legal working age |Yes |16 |Labor Code: article 403<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto-lei/Del5452.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto-lei/Del5452.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |May 1, 1943 |- |Minimum age for hazardous work |Yes |18 |Hazardous Work List: article 2<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2007-2010/2008/Decreto/D6481.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2007-2010/2008/Decreto/D6481.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |June 12, 2008 |- |Prohibition of forced labor |Yes | |Penal Code: articles 149 and 149-A<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_Ato2015-2018/2016/Lei/L13344.htm|title=L13344|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |Dec 7, 1940 Oct 6, 2016 |- |Prohibition of child trafficking |No | |Penal Code: article 149-A; Child and Adolescent Statute: article 244A<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/L8069.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/L8069.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |Oct 6, 2016 July 13, 1990 |- |Prohibition of commercial sexual exploitation of children |Yes | |Penal Code: articles 218-A 218-B, and 227–228<ref name=":9" /> Child and Adolescent Statute: articles 240–241 and 244A<ref name=":10" /> |Dec 7, 1940 July 13, 1990 |- |Prohibition of child involvement in illicit activities |Yes | |National System of Public Policies on Drugs: articles 33 and 40<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2004-2006/2006/lei/l11343.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/_ato2004-2006/2006/lei/l11343.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Child and Adolescent Statute: article 244-B |Aug 23, 2006 July 13, 1990 |- |Prohibition of military recruitment | | | | |- |State compulsory |Yes |18 |Military Service Law: article 5<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/l4375.htm|title=L4375|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |Aug 17, 1964 |- |State voluntary |Yes |17 |Military Service Regulation: article 127<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto/d57654.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto/d57654.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> |Jan 20, 1966 |- |Compulsory education age |Yes |17 | rowspan="2" |National Education Law: article 4<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/Leis/L9394.htm|title=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/Leis/L9394.htm|website=planalto.gov.br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> | rowspan="2" |Dec 20, 1996 |- |Provision of free education |Yes | |} The [[Ministry of Labour and Employment (Brazil)|Ministry of Labor]] (MTE) is the major government institution in charge of labor law enforcement. The responsibilities of this institution include conducting child labor inspections, enforcing child labor laws, and dispatching inspection teams (inspectors, labor prosecutors, Federal Police officers, and other law enforcement officials) to sites where potential child labor activity is suspected.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trabalho.gov.br/trab_estrang_ing/default.asp|title=Página inicial|website=trabalho.gov.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> However, existing gaps in the operations of MTE hinder the full enforcement of labor laws. 7,491 child labor inspections were conducted in the year 2017, but insufficient funding limits the abilities of regions where there are no local MTE offices to conduct inspections.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Trabalho Infantil nos ODS|last=|first=|publisher=Fórum Nacional de Prevenção e Erradicação do Trabalho Infantil (FNPETI)|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> In July 2017, inspectors were prevented from performing child labor inspections in the states of São Paulo and Rio Grande do Norte.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/brasil/ministerio-do-trabalho-nega-pedidos-de-fiscalizacao-por-falta-de-recurso-diz-mpt-21634439|title=Ministério do Trabalho nega pedidos de fiscalização por falta de recurso, diz MPT|date=2017-07-26|work=O Globo|access-date=2018-10-11|language=pt-BR}}</ref>
== Government policies == [[File:Trabalho infantil em Goianésia do Pará.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Children awaiting permission to sell their products on a long-distance bus in northern Brazil in 2012.]]
=== National Plan to Combat Sexual Violence Against Children and Adolescents (2013–2020)<ref>Plano Nacional de Enfrentamento da Violência Sexual contra Crianças e Adolescentes. (2013)http://www.crianca.mppr.mp.br/arquivos/File/publi/sedh/08_2013_pnevsca.pdf</ref>=== This plan reaffirms uncompromising commitment to defend the rights of children and adolescents, especially those who are in threatening situations where fundamental rights are violated. Specifically, this plan "identifies strategies to prevent the sexual exploitation of children, protect children’s rights, and assist child victims".<ref name=":11" /> The goals of the plan include:
# Ensure preventive action against abuse or sexual exploitation of children and adolescents, primarily through education, awareness and self-defense. # Ensure specialized assistance to children and adolescents in situations of sexual abuse or exploitation, by trained and specialized professionals, as well as ensuring care for the person who commits sexual violence, while respecting the diversity of ethnic-racial condition, gender, religion, culture, sexual orientation, etc. # Update the regulatory framework on sexual crimes, combat impunity, provide skilled reporting and accountability services. # Promote the active participation of children and adolescents for the defense of their rights in the development and implementation of protection policies. # Strengthen national joint, regional and local coping and the elimination of abuse or sexual exploitation involving media, networking, forums, commissions, councils. # Understanding the expressions of abuse or sexual exploitation of children and adolescents through diagnostics, data collection, studies and research.
=== National Plan for the Eradication of Forced Labor<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://reporterbrasil.org.br/documentos/novoplanonacional.pdf|title=2º Plano Nacional para a Erradicação do Trabalho Escravo|last=|first=|date=2008|website=Conselho Nacional de Justiça|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>=== Forced labor is an integral part of the child labor issue in Brazil. Some children are forced to do domestic work or play in the soccer clubs; some children are forced to produce coffee and manioc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRC/C/BRA/CO/2-4&Lang=en|title=Treaty bodies Download|website=tbinternet.ohchr.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> The current version of the National Plan for the Eradication, introduced in 2008, establishes the policy framework in combating forced labor. Top goals of this plan include:
# Keep the eradication of forced labor as a priority for the state. # Establish integrated operational strategies of action in relation to the preventive actions of the executive bodies, prosecutors and civil society in order to eradicate forced labor. # Create and maintain a database containing information of key players involved in the fight against forced labor to assist in prevention and repression actions and drafting of laws. # Provide national and regional mobile inspection teams in sufficient numbers to meet the complaints and demands of the annual plan of inspection.
=== National Education Plan (2014-2024)<ref>Ministério da Educação. Planejando a Próxima Década - Conhecendo as 20 Metas do Plano Nacional de Educação. 2014<nowiki/>http://pne.mec.gov.br/images/pdf/pne_conhecendo_20_metas.pdf</ref> === Education is believed to be the best solution to child labor issues to a certain extent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unric.org/pt/actualidade/17859|title=Educação é fundamental para combater trabalho infantil|website=unric.org|language=pt-pt|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> The National Education Plan is a demonstration of the determination of the Brazilian government to improve the quality and accessibility of education. This plan entails 20 goals encompassing basic education for children and also aims to promote the quality of higher education. For example, goal #14 of the plan states the objective to gradually increase the number of enrollments in graduate school.
== Social programs == There are many social programs in Brazil that aim to address child labor directly or indirectly. Some are funded by government, such as [[Bolsa Família]], a family welfare program introduced during [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula's]] presidency. Some take the form of social media, gathering internet attention such as ''#ChegaDeTrabalhoInfantil (#stopchildlabor)''.
=== National Program to Eradicate Child Labor<ref name=":12">http://www.chegadetrabalhoinfantil.org.br/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/comissao-municipal-do-peti.pdf</ref>=== This program is a set of actions that aim to remove children and adolescents under 16 from early work, excluding apprenticeships from 14 years of age. Besides ensuring a direct transfer of income to families, the program offers the inclusion of children and young people in counseling and follow-up services. Attendance at school is a requirement. It is initiated and administered by the Ministry of Social Development.<ref name=":12" /> The Federal Government pays a monthly grant: of R $25 per child in activity for the family who withdraws the child labor, in municipalities, in rural or urban areas, with a population of less than 250,000 inhabitants; of R $40 per child, in urban activity, in capitals, metropolitan regions and municipalities with a population 250,000 inhabitants. The benefited family has to ensure a higher than 85% attendance of their kids above clearing them from child labor to receive the grant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.caixa.gov.br/programas-sociais/peti/Paginas/default.aspx|title=PETI - Programas Sociais {{!}} Caixa|website=caixa.gov.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
===[[Bolsa Família]]=== Bolsa Família is a social welfare program of the Government of Brazil, part of the Fome Zero network of federal assistance programs. Bolsa Família provides financial aid to poor Brazilian families; and if they have children, families must ensure that the children attend school and are vaccinated. If they exceed the total of permitted school absences, they are dropped from the program and their funds are suspended. In 2017, 93.1 percent of 6–15 years old achieve 85 percent school attendance; 82.3 percent of 16–17 years old met the minimum requirement of 75% school attendance.<ref name=":11" /> However, studies suggest that the program, while it has improved girls' school participation and educational performance, has had little impact on boys.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=de Brauw|first=Alan|last2=Gilligan|first2=Daniel O.|last3=Hoddinott|first3=John|last4=Roy|first4=Shalini|date=2015-06|title=The Impact of Bolsa Família on Schooling|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.worlddev.2015.02.001|journal=World Development|volume=70|pages=303–316|doi=10.1016/j.worlddev.2015.02.001|issn=0305-750X}}</ref>
=== #StopChildLabor Campaign === In 2017, the Public Ministry of Labor (MPT) began a campaign under the [[hashtag]] "#StopChildLabor" that seeks the engagement of Internet users in social networks, encouraging them to post the hashtag in support of the cause against child labor. The campaign received support from celebrities, including musicians [[Daniel (Brazilian singer)|Daniel]], [[Chitãozinho and Xororó]], former volleyball player [[Maurício Lima]] and former basketball player [[Hortência Marcari]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.justificando.com/2017/06/09/mpt-lanca-campanha-contra-exploracao-do-trabalho-infantil/|title=MPT lança campanha contra à exploração do trabalho infantil|date=2017-06-09|work=Justificando|access-date=2018-10-13|language=pt-BR}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |+Other Programs !Name !Organizations in charge !Description |- |Living Together and Strengthening Links Program<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mds.gov.br/assistencia-social-suas/servicos-e-programas/servicos-de-convivencia-e-fortalecimento-de-vinculos|title=Convivência e Fortalecimento de Vínculos|last=|first=|date=|website=http://mds.gov.br/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> |Ministry of Social Development |The Service of Coexistence and Strengthening of Links (SCFV) carries out group consultations. Artistic, cultural, leisure and sports activities are provided according to the age groups. It is a form of planned social intervention that creates challenging situations, stimulates and guides vulnerable groups in the construction and reconstruction of their individual, collective and family histories and experiences. |- |National Program on Job Training and Employment<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://portal.mec.gov.br/pronatec|title=Pronatec|access-date=2018-10-13|language=pt-br}}</ref> |Ministry of Education |Expanding the offer of Vocational and Technological Education (EPT) courses through programs, project and actions of technical and financial assistance. High school students are also among the recipients of beneficiaries. |- |[[South–South cooperation|South-South Cooperation]] Projects |[[International Labour Organization|ILO]] [[United Nations Development Programme|UNDP]]
Ministry of Social Development
Ministry of Labor |"In 2017, the government hosted representatives from six countries to discuss ILO’s child labor predictor model and the redesign of the PETI program."<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nacoesunidas.org/brasil-e-outros-seis-paises-latino-americanos-testam-ferramenta-estatistica-sobre-trabalho-infantil/|title=Brasil e outros seis países latino-americanos testam ferramenta estatística sobre trabalho infantil|date=2017-09-20|work=ONU Brasil|access-date=2018-10-14|language=pt-BR}}</ref> |}

page.title: Corruption in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

revision.text:
{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.svg|150 px]]}} '''Corruption in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]''', once legendary, has diminished in recent years, but continues to exceed corruption in most states. The [[BBC]]'s DRC country profile calls its recent history "one of civil war and corruption."<ref> {{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-13283212 |title=DR Congo country profile |date= 10 February 2016 |accessdate=29 July 2016 }} </ref> [[President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|President]] [[Joseph Kabila]] established the Commission of Repression of Economic Crimes upon his ascension to power in 2001.<ref name=d> {{cite book |last=Werve |first=Jonathan |year=2006 |title=The Corruption Notebooks 2006 |pages=57 }} </ref>
== History ==
[[Mobutu Sese Seko]] ruled [[Zaire]] from 1965 to 1997, looting his country's wealth for personal use to such a degree that critics coined the term "[[kleptocracy]]". A relative once explained how the government illicitly collected revenue: "Mobutu would ask one of us to go to the bank and take out a million. We'd go to an intermediary and tell him to get five million. He would go to the bank with Mobutu's authority, and take out ten. Mobutu got one, and we took the other nine."<ref name=a> {{cite book |last=Ludwig |first=Arnold M. |year=2002 |title=King of the Mountain: The Nature of Political Leadership |pages=72 }} </ref> Mobutu institutionalized corruption to prevent political rivals from challenging his control, leading to an [[Economy of the Democratic Republic of the Congo#1990s|economic collapse in 1996]].<ref name=b> {{cite book |last=Nafziger |first=E. Wayne |author2=Raimo Frances Stewart |year=2000|title=War, Hunger, and Displacement: The Origins of Humanitarian Emergencies |pages=261 }}</ref> Mobutu allegedly stole up to US$4 billion while in office.<ref name=c> {{cite book |last=Mesquita |first=Bruce Bueno de |year=2003 |title=The Logic of Political Survival |pages=167 }} </ref>
In 2017, [[Reuters]] unveiled a scheme involving overpriced [[biometric passport]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/congo-passports/ |title=Congo's pricey passport scheme sends millions of dollars offshore |date= 13 April 2017 |accessdate=14 April 2017 }} </ref>
==Corruption Perception Index== {{Main|Corruption Perception Index}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="font-weight:bold" valign="bottom" | width="93.75" Height="11.25"| Year | width="93.75" | Ranking | width="92.25" | Countries ranked | width="92.25" | Rating
|- valign="bottom" | Height="11.25" | 2004 | 133 | 145 | 2.0<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2004 2004/cpi/surveys_indices/policy_research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | -
|- valign="bottom" | Height="11.25" | 2005 | 144 | 158 | 2.1<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2005 2005/cpi/surveys_indices/policy_research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | -
|- valign="bottom" | Height="11.25" | 2006 | 156 | 163 | 2.0<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2006 2006/cpi/surveys_indices/policy_research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | -
|- valign="bottom" | Height="11.25" | 2007 | 168 | 179 | 1.9<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2007 2007/cpi/surveys_indices/policy_research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | -
|- valign="bottom" | Height="11.25" | 2008 | 171 | 180 | 1.7<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2008 2008/cpi/surveys_indices/policy_research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | -
|}
In 2015 [[Transparency International]] ranked the DRC 147 out of 167 countries in the [[Corruption Perception Index]], tying [[Chad]] and the [[Republic of the Congo]] with a score of 22/100.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/cpi2015#results-table|title=Transparency International - The Global Anti-Corruption Coalition|last=e.V.|first=|date=|website=www.transparency.org|publisher=Transparency International|access-date=2016-11-04}}</ref>
== The Kabila Regime == [[Laurent Kabila]] led an insurgence group against [[Mobutu Sese Seko|Mobutu]] and quickly assumed power after [[Mobutu Sese Seko|Mobutu]] was overthrown<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.antigenocide.org/images/D.R._Congo_7_Dec_06_Kabila_Promises_New_Era_for_Congo_Nation_Inaugurates_First_Freely_Elected_Leader_Since_1960.pdf|title=Kabila Promises New Era for Congo|last=Isango|first=Eddy|date=December 7, 2006|website=Antigenocide.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. During this time period, [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Kabila]] issued a statement making himself president with near absolute power in the government<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/200705711?pq-origsite=gscholar|title=Log In - ProQuest|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>. With people supporting him for overthrowing Mobutu, he was not initially met with much public opposition<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Schatzberg|first=Michael G.|date=1997-10-01|title=Beyond Mobutu: Kabila and the Congo|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/16852|journal=Journal of Democracy|language=en|volume=8|issue=4|pages=70–84|doi=10.1353/jod.1997.0065|issn=1086-3214}}</ref>. However, [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Kabila's]] and his government's goals for the regime were said to be unclear and vague<ref name=":4" />. He refused immediate elections in fear of the country returning to [[Mobutism|Mobutuism]], and continued to postpone promised elections.<ref name=":3" />The constitution was not changed, and he and his peers exploited resources for their personal benefit <ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/sites/default/files/attached-files/corruption_in_the_drc_.pdf|title=Corruption and Infrastructure Megaprojects in the DR Congo|last=Nguh|first=Augustin|date=December 2013|website=International Rivers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Laurent Kabila]], led a regime that upheld corruption through [[clientelism]] by appointing his clients as cabinet members <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title=The Democratic Republic of the Congo? Corruption, Patronage, and Competitive Authoritarianism in the DRC on JSTOR|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/10.2979/aft.2010.56.4.42.pdf?refreqid=excelsior:4fa0de2df16e34a5ae170c0a31c78886|language=en|doi=10.2979/aft.2010.56.4.42.pdf}}</ref>. Under the [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Kabila]] regime, the DRC has failed to pull itself out of its “[[State collapse|collapsed state]]” status from when [[Mobutu Sese Seko|Mobutu]] was in power <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reyntjens|first=Filip|date=2001|title=Briefing: The Democratic Republic of Congo, from Kabila to Kabila|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/3518770|journal=African Affairs|volume=100|issue=399|pages=311–317}}</ref>. The government has failed to implement security and human rights reforms, free media, and the decentralization of power <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dizolele|first=Mvemba|date=July 2010|title=The Mirage of Democracy in the DRC|url=http://friendsofthecongo.org/pdf/dizolele_democracy.pdf|journal=Journal of Democracy|volume=21|pages=143|via=National Endowment for Democracy and The Johns Hopkins University Press}}</ref>. The economy plummeted, forcing workers to be underpaid and living conditions to deteriorate <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.africaportal.org|title=Africa Portal|last=Mills|first=Greg|date=February 2002|website=Africa Portal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>. [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Laurent Kabila]] was killed in 2001 by one of his body guards in an attempted [[coup d'état]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Christensen|first=Christian|date=2004|title=Political Victims and Media Focus: The Killings of Laurent Kabila, Zoran Djindjic, Anna Lindh and Pim Fortuyn|url=http://site.iugaza.edu.ps/tissa/files/2010/02/Political_Victims_and_Media_Focus.pdf|journal=Journal for Crime, Conflict and the Media|volume=2|pages=17|via=JC2M}}</ref>.
During that time period, The [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Democratic Republic of Congo]] received a score of 1.9 out of 10 in the [[Corruption Perceptions Index|Corruption Perception Index]], which reveals high levels of corruption <ref name=":0" />.
His son, [[Joseph Kabila]] was elected president after [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila|Laurent Kabila]]'s death<ref name=":1" />. [[Joseph Kabila]] is working with the [[World Bank Group|World Bank]] to curtail corruption and improve economy<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/UN/UNPAN023260.pdf|title=Democratic Republic of Congo|last=|first=|date=|website=United Nations|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. In addition, the Commission of Economic Crimes was implemented in 2001 by President [[Joseph Kabila]]. Nonetheless, there are still reports of high ranking officials exploiting resources for their personal benefit <ref name=":2" />.
